network_2.name: Kendall Square
network_2.txt:
The Kendal Square District is a 42-acre urban renewal zone located between MIT’s campus in Cambridge 
 Massachusetts and the Charles River. Over the past three decades, this area has become one of the most prolific 
 research and development districts in the country, attracting thousands of business across a range of industries 
 from renewable energy and robotics, to artificial intelligence and life-sciences. Despite the success, the area 
 functions poorly as a community. With little housing and few amenities, most workers commute each day, leaving 
 the area  lifeless after hours. 
 This CityScope table presents a hypothetical “thought experiment” scenarios that could dramatically reduce emissions 
 while improving quality of life and the economic potential of the area. Interventions include deep retrofit of existing 
 buildings, live-work symmetry for net-zero commuting, walkable access to amenities, hyper-efficient transformable 
 housing, lightweight autonomous mobility, production of resources near the point of consumption, low-carbon diet, 
 and high-density baseload electrical power. 
 By manipulating building types and land-uses on developable sites, stakeholders can iterate and scenario test while 
 understanding understand the urban performance across multiple indicators displayed on the screen and projected 
 on the model. You are encouraged to test your intuition.
